awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Assessing the response of tropical temperature to global forcings since the Last Glacial Maximum
awd_abstract_narration:
The tropics are the heat engine of the planet and home to about 40% of the world's population.  However, we know very little about how and why tropical climate has changed through time.  This project will develop a temperature record in the Rwenzori Mountains of Uganda covering the last ice age to the present to improve the understanding of the mechanisms that cause tropical climate change and the role of the tropics in the global climate system.  The Rwenzori Mountains are among the very few glaciated tropical areas where such long-term, objective data can be obtained. 

This project will utilize two different sources of climate information including: 1) surface exposure dating of glacial moraines (ridges that mark former glacial extents) and glacial modeling, and 2) chemical analyses of lake sediment cores.  The project will entail fieldwork in Uganda to collect glacial moraine samples and lake sediment cores. It will evaluate how tropical African temperature changes relate to similar reconstructions in tropical South America, and how they correspond to changes in solar radiation, Greenland and Antarctic ice sheet extents, and atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations.  The project will advance the effort to learn how the global climate worked over the last approximately 20,000 years.

This award is cofunded by the Paleo Perspectives on Climate Change Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical lands are warming as a consequence of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. The worldwide retreat of tropical mountain glaciers is one of the most visible signals of this warming. Climate models predict that, in the coming decades, the high tropical atmosphere will warm faster than anywhere on Earth except the Arctic, yet scientists debate the extent to which tropical mountain temperature and glaciers will change in the future. Tropical mountain glacier extents are influenced by many climatic factors, such as snowfall, and we lack long observational records from tropical mountains that might document how temperatures have changed through time.

This project documented changes in temperature and glacial extents through time in the Rwenzori Mountains, one of only three glaciated mountain ranges in Africa. Through the project, scientists and students at Brown University, Dartmouth College, and Makerere University in Uganda tested the extent to which temperature influenced Rwenzori Mountain glacier extents, the factors influencing temperature changes through time, and the relationships between high- and low-elevation temperature changes to evaluate the sensitivity of tropical mountain climates through time.

To accomplish these goals, scientists collected sediment core samples from high-elevation lakes in the Rwenzori, with sediments that were deposited from the last ice age (21,000 years ago) to the present day.  They used chemical analyses of these sediments to determine changes in temperature and precipitation through time. By comparing these data to records of glacier extent, using both geological records of the glaciers and models, they showed that temperature changes account for the vast majority of changes in the size of glaciers. Temperatures in these mountains tracked long-term changes in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, and the temperature changes in the mountains were nearly twice as large as changes at low elevations.  Putting these data together, these results show that changes in the Earth’s greenhouse effect caused large changes in temperature and glacier extent in tropical African mountains through time, including changes in mountain temperature that dwarfed those at low elevations. 

These results comprise an important dataset to test the ability of climate models to predict climate change in tropical mountains through time, demonstrated the importance and impacts of elevation-dependent warming, and demonstrated the importance of temperature change to tropical mountain glaciers.  All of these findings have important implications for the changes tropical mountains will experience in the near future.

This project contributed substantially to the US scientific workforce and provided opportunities for seven students, including three from historically underrepresented groups, to participate in international, interdisciplinary research.  The project supported a graduate student who earned their PhD in the Earth Sciences and has gone on to an Assistant Professor position.  This student contributed to substantive educational partnerships for between Brown and the Providence Public School System to educate students about the Earth Sciences and climate change. The project also provided research and training opportunities for six undergraduates who are either continuing their studies or have gone on to careers in science and technology.
